Any Participating Player who is eligible to represent more than one (1) Football Association on account of his nationality of one (1) country (e.g. a player with Chinese nationality may be eligible to represent three (3) different Member Associations)and wishes to participate in the Competition utilising the nationality of a Member Association must demonstrate one (1) of the following:
28.4.1. that he has participated in an official competition for a representative team of the relevant Member Association; or
28.4.2. that he was eligible to participate for a representative team of the relevant Member Association in accordance with the FIFA Regulations Governing the Application of the Statutes at least one (1) year before the date of the Participating Player’s registration for the Competition.

28.2.2. that he is eligible to participate for the representative team of an AFC Member Association in accordance with Article 5-8 of the Regulation Governing the Application of the FIFA Statues.

28.4.2. that he was eligible to participate for a representative team of the relevant Member Association in accordance with the FIFA Regulations Governing the Application of the Statutes at least one (1) year before the date of the Participating Player’s registration for the Competition.

Ian Holloway reveals he was approached to become new manager of the Hong Kong national team, and expresses an interest
Former Blackpool boss discusses approach live on Sunday football magazine show in UK

PUBLISHED : Sunday, 03 February, 2019, 9:12pm

Former Premier League manager Ian Holloway revealed on Sunday that he had been approached about taking over the vacant Hong Kong national team manager’s job.

Speaking on Sky Sports’ “Goals on Sunday”, the former Leicester, Blackpool and Crystal Palace boss said he had been approached through a third-party about potentially taking over the role vacated by Gary White last December.

The 55-year-old would represent something of a coup for the Hong Kong Football Association given his reputation built over a number of years managing at the top level of the English game.

https://twitter.com/i/status/1092042003615891458

Most recently Holloway was in charge of Championship club QPR but left the role in May last year.

For his part, Holloway expressed an interest in the post joking: “Imagine how good the food would be.

“I had a bit of a weird call the other day [to become the new Hong Kong manager] ... whether I’ll get it or not, I don’t know,” Holloway said.

The informal-sounding nature of the approach would suggest it is far from a done deal, however, Hong Kong supporters will take heart from the fact that the HKFA is aiming high in recruiting a replacement for White, who left suddenly in December to take over as manager of Tokyo Verdy in the J2 League.

HKFA vice chairman Pui Kwan-kay said it was still too early in the day to comment on the next boss.

“The recruitment process for the national team manager is in progress and it would not be appropriate to comment on any of the candidates at this stage.

“A proper announcement will be made when we have appointed the person,” he added.

Ian Holloway reveals he was approached to become new manager of the Hong Kong national team, and expresses an interest
Former Blackpool boss discusses approach live on Sunday football magazine show in UK

PUBLISHED : Sunday, 03 February, 2019, 9:12pm

Former Premier League manager Ian Holloway revealed on Sunday that he had been approached about taking over the vacant Hong Kong national team manager’s job.

Speaking on Sky Sports’ “Goals on Sunday”, the former Leicester, Blackpool and Crystal Palace boss said he had been approached through a third-party about potentially taking over the role vacated by Gary White last December.

The 55-year-old would represent something of a coup for the Hong Kong Football Association given his reputation built over a number of years managing at the top level of the English game.

https://twitter.com/i/status/1092042003615891458

Most recently Holloway was in charge of Championship club QPR but left the role in May last year.

For his part, Holloway expressed an interest in the post joking: “Imagine how good the food would be.

“I had a bit of a weird call the other day [to become the new Hong Kong manager] ... whether I’ll get it or not, I don’t know,” Holloway said.

The informal-sounding nature of the approach would suggest it is far from a done deal, however, Hong Kong supporters will take heart from the fact that the HKFA is aiming high in recruiting a replacement for White, who left suddenly in December to take over as manager of Tokyo Verdy in the J2 League.

HKFA vice chairman Pui Kwan-kay said it was still too early in the day to comment on the next boss.

“The recruitment process for the national team manager is in progress and it would not be appropriate to comment on any of the candidates at this stage.

“A proper announcement will be made when we have appointed the person,” he added.
